thread.title: Sirius funding secured by Independence

author: Tess Ingram
title: Sirius funding secured by Independence
text:
Independence Group has secured a $550 million finance facility to fund its proposed acquisition of Sirius Resources and the development of the Nova nickel mine in Western Australia.
Nova, the jewel in Sirius' crown which drove Independence's $1.8 billion cash and scrip offer for the nickel hopeful, is in development and expected to commence production in late 2016.
In terms of an overall cash spend to repay debt we believe we will be in quite a stronger position than Nova.
Scott Steinkrug, Independence Group chief financial officer Independence Group chief executive Peter Bradford told an analyst call on Wednesday the new syndicated facility agreement with National Australia Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group provided the company with "significantly better operational and financial flexibility" than the $440 million debt facility Sirius had secured for the project's development.
Independence's $550 million finance facility comprises of a five-year, $200 million unsecured revolving credit facility which would be used to part-fund the cash component of the Sirius offer and acquisition costs. A five-year, $350 million unsecured amortising term debt facility will be used to refinance the Sirius facility and fund the project's development and operation.
Advertisement Chief financial officer Scott Steinkrug said the agreement put the company in a stronger position to repay future debt than if it had stuck with the existing Nova project finance facility.
"There is a shorter term loan so, we talking seven years moving down to five years, lower margins in the construction phase, better utilisation of the funds we have and we can also utilise the existing cash coming out of the operations," he said. "So in terms of an overall cash spend to repay debt we believe we will be in quite a stronger position than Nova."
Credit Suisse analyst Paul McTaggart said Independence "could have continued with the Nova facility but this seems to provide more flexibility in terms of not constricting cash".
Independence owns the Long nickel mine, Jaguar zinc-copper mine and a 30 per cent stake in the Tropicana gold project, all in Western Australia.
Blemished report The company's June quarter report was blemished by a close to halving in its profit after tax for the period, down from $14.7 million a year earlier to $7.5 million.
Independence said the result was due to the impact lower copper sales at Jaguar, lower payable nickel volumes at Long and higher exploration expenses had on earnings.
However, preliminary full-year results were strong, with the miner delivering the highest levels of revenue, at $499 million, and net cash flows, at $202 million, from operating activities in its 13-year history.
Mr Bradford also revealed the diversified miner would postpone a decision on the development of its $233 million Stockman zinc and copper project in Victoria until at least early 2017 as the company was "unlikely to proceed with a second development while developing Nova". A decision was expected to be made in October 2015.
He added the company was looking forward to its first cashflow from Nova in early 2017 if the proposal is approved by Sirius shareholders at a meeting expected to be held in early September.
